comments.commentBody: Just three? You do yourself an injustice, Mr Douthat!

Dear Mr. Douthat,

I appreciated this piece on your confessions regarding mis-predictions. All too often these things do not go recognized publicly in the media, and they are simply forgotten, but your ability to come clean on these mis-predictions should now have cleared your conscience and let us all get a good night's sleep!

Seriously, though, I haven't seen too many op-ed writers who have the courage you showed.

Thank you for your candor.

best,

Daniel Palomo

As an unabashed Progressive there is no one I respect more than Ross Douthat. His willingness to call it as it is speaks volumes for his integrity which is so rare for any pundit at this time in America.
Thank you Mr. Douthat!
Good on you, Mr. Douthat. All pundits and commentators should do the same. And please try to cut the President some slack; he has the most difficult job in the world.

Putin didn't offer Obama a "face saving out", Putin caved. When Obama
said he'd put it before the American people he convinced Putin that he
was serious about bombing Syria. That is why Putin agreed soon after
to a treaty. Obama used the classic tactic of "Saber Rattling" and
accomplished his goals without a shot being fired. You'd think the guy
could get a little credit for that but not in this scenario that the right has
concocted.

"Yet I was only partly right, because I figured he'd stop bending by now, and he hasn't. Atheists? Wow."

Um... Your bending is the rest of the world's extending an olive branch. What's wrong with that?

Rima:

Perhaps you didn't misspend your youth getting to know the Roman Catholic Church very well indeed, to the point of dialectics with Jesuits. If you had, you likely would express every bit as much astonishment as I and many others at the willingness of this pontiff to open channels of communication with communities whose members the Catholic hierarchy sadly apportioned, on a regular basis, among the various levels and bolgias of Dante's favorite summer spot.
I actually lived in a Catholic school for several years. This pope is consistent with everything I saw and learned.

Your first error wasn't an error, but it was mine. You praised Boehner, while I buried him.

He did perform miracles this year in keeping cats herded, until close to the end. But consider: the Tea Party insisted on a one-year deferral of ACA implementation, and shut down government over it, despite Boehner's harrumphs. Yet ... how much would Mr. Obama give to have the chance back to accept the offer, then turn around and say to them "now, this is what I want from YOU!" ObamaCare's ratings as of the last CNN poll are 35% in favor, 62% actively disapprove of it. Unless the president discovers some talent for magic, this will figure in the mid-terms next November. So ... just how bad WAS Boehner, after all, from his perspective? And, guess what? It looks like we're gonna get a budget, no mean feat.

You were wrong about Pope Francis and I was right. This is a man put there to re-swell the Church's ranks, regardless of how far dogma must be bent. Yet I was only partly right, because I figured he'd stop bending by now, and he hasn't. Atheists? Wow.

As to Syria, this is a story not yet fully told, and we should hold in abeyance any judgments about how it's likely to end, for all our dithering. Ditto for Iran -- I honestly believe that they're within six months of nuclear "break-out", and our policy pivot to mere containment is going to be horrifically impactful to the region and to Mr. Obama's prestige.

You didn't do too bad, Ross; and there's always next year. Happy New Year!

Any American President is always a credible actor on the world stage.

The power to launch a nuclear holocaust that could end life on the planet provides a lot of credibility.
As his predecessor painfully showed, that awesome power should never be invested in a cowardly fool trying to be a tough guy.

3 cherry-picked confessions?

How about adding this self-serving excuse for a column to the list?

Great story and a great game in store.

This one's for all the marbles.

Winner take all.

Must-win.

Etc. etc.

They're airing it in the NY market, which is slightly unusual. Usually they show the Jets game on CBS, Giants on FOX, and one other game on either CBS or FOX, plus the night game. Tomorrow: Jets, Giants, Patriots, and Bears, plus the night game.
Mr. Douthat, thank you for mentioning these three areas where you were in error. It's a very nice start to what I trust will eventually become a very long list. May we assist?

Mr. Douthat,

I appreciate your perspective on many issues, and look forward to your column every Saturday evening. I am, as most NYTimes readers, to your left on many issues, but you give readers a different perspective that I have gained from profitably.

Dimitri

Gee, there are 54 critics right here in the comments so far, and I'm sure there'll be 540 (or 1,540, or more) by the end of the day. Sometimes I think that Mr. Douthat's sole function is to be our personal New York Times piñata!
I think, like publicly traded companies, that you should not be allowed to conduct your own audit. Find a critic to do it for you.
In this age, a pundit is one who brags about himself to no end.
Do you notice a pattern here?  Your conservative dogma is showing.

Philip Tetlock's research on expert political opinion suggests that a simple extrapolation model of forecasting -- things will keep on keeping on, only a little more so -- tends to beat marginally the predictions of experts, who face incentives to be interesting.

“often wrong, rarely accountable.” not only describes pundits, it also fits the weather-person on TV. I'd like to have a concordance of your columns of the past year and run it by the list in Tim Egan's column today. Then again, all my comments for the year would be fair game too.
Great clip, but the sound effects were extremely distracting.

As John said, "when I find myself in times of times of trouble, Mother Mary comes to me," and really Paul  too. Thinking backwards into the future we find the mistakes we've made to either be justifications for further absent minded blunders or a come to truth assessment that is a real confession and a plea of forgiveness. Douthat appears to forgo confession except in the title, but Let It Be, as questioning or correcting propagandist's nonsense is useless.

Ross Douthat, many thanks, your overwrought self-criticism was a delight to read!

Re your 3 mistakes - #1, John Boehner isn't a hero; he's still being twisted in the wind like a pinata by Ted Cruz and the Tea Partiers. Hopefully he's having a nice long Christmas/New Year's holiday while the poor million plus jobless of our country feel their unemployment benefits stop (as of today)

As to #2, your misunderestimating Pope Francis and his electrifying affect on the Catholic Church all over the world and here in the US as media hype. The Argentinian Pope is the best thing to happen to Catholicism since the Year Dot. Finally, a man of humility, kindness, compassion and wonder, a human in the Papal See! May Pope Francis live long and well.

Your admitted 3rd mistake, the worst, averring that a Congressional defeat on the bombing of Syria issue would "basically finish off Obama as a credible actor on the world stage" was a stinker. Oh, PLEASE! Frankly Scarlett, it's great to see you humble your braggadocio as 2013 fades into history next week. But I'm not looking forward - with undiluted pleasure and enthusiasm - to more of your Republican apocalyptic predictions in 2014..

The bike lanes and more people-friendly land-use policies, such as Times Square pedestrian amenities are awesome!
Two major things the author forgot were the Mayor's incredible support of the High Line Project, which has been and continues to be an incredible success and an example of great City Planning.
On the opposite side, Bloomberg's efforts in suppressing freedom of speech of the Occupy movement, using a NYPD-military approach was a complete waste of resources, completely unnecessary, and of course completely wrong to do.

The Calory (sic) Counts, expanding places that have fresh air, free of tobacco smoke and the efforts to cut trans-fats out of foods, as a Dietitian/someone who as worked as a public health professional, I also applaud.

Don't be so quick to pull the trigger on Rex.  You want examples?  He's the only coach in the history of the Jets to take them to two consecutive AFC Championships.  Bill Parcells didn't do it.  Neither did Walt Michaels, Joe Walton, Herm Edwards, or the rest of the parade.  Rex brought in Bart Scott, Jim Leonhard, Mike Pettine.  He brought spirit and attitude.  I'm as fed up and frustrated as any Jets fan, but the fact that the Jets lack a respectable quarterback and have no receiving corps is not all on Rex.  He's not the one turning the ball over or committing all the penalties.

1) Fighting with Tannenbaum to make Wilkerson the first Jets pick (#30 overall) in the 2011 draft;

2) Bringing Mike Pettine with him from Baltimore and making him the DC;

3) Converting from a 4-3 defense under Mangini to a 3-4.

These were major positive decisions demonstrating good judgment by the Head Coach. A 4th would be deciding that he didn't need to replace Pettine from outside when he left this year.

Jets 7-9, or a little better after pre season projections of 3-13, 4-12?  With a rookie qb with limited wrs and issues at ol, oh and also in the defensive secondary.   Marty M did a pretty good job.  Rex kept the team motivated.  Who's out there at HC that's a big step up from today?  That will come here?  Seen this before, change for change's sake....  Stay the course, build the roster (primarily through the draft).  Obviously very difficult to get to SB, let's try to get back to playoffs.

I have been thinking this for some time now: How well can you evaluate the receiving corps when the quarterback has been so uneven?

Or to put it another way, how can Nelson, Cumberland, Winslow look so good one week and so bad the next?

By far the biggest weakness on this team is the defensive secondary, where nobody had anything resembling an above average year. I think Antonio Allen made real strides, and Milliner is nothing close to the bust that many critics have said he is. Cro at full strength is at best an average corner - he can be broken down by top receivers, and has been even in his best years. We can't seriously bring back Ed Reed, certainly not as a starter. So we need serious competition back there, and you can't rely on the draft for starting secondary players. You need too much instinct and recognition to play well back there,

Yes we can go into next camp with Geno in competition with an experienced veteran, and may the best man win. And if Geno shows signs of becoming more consistent, amen and let the growth continue. And if not, let the veteran step in, and start planning for the next franchise QB to be drafted.

There is no need to pay big money for a receiver, because rookie receivers CAN step in and start. And yes we need a solid pick there. Anyone who has watched Dez Bryant knows what an ace receiver can do for a quarterback. But I do not consider receiver a wasteland on this team. With a consistent quarterback, we have guys who can make plays.

And by the way, for reasons I have stated before, tomorrow will be Rex' last as HC/NYJ.

He will be somebody else's head coach within a week, and my money is on him going to the Redskins.
